title: 5 possible opponents for Conor McGregor as he reveals 3-fight comeback plan
text:

Conor McGregor announced his return to the UFC - then plotted a three-fight journey back to the top.

The Irishman will fight in Las Vegas on January 18 in his first bout since he was choked out by lightweight champion Khabib Nurmagomedov last October.

McGregor did not reveal his opponent but there are several likely contenders.

He then wants to fight the winner of Nate Diaz’s clash with Jorge Masvidal next weekend before rounding off 2020 by facing the winner of Nurmagomedov’s next defence against Tony Ferguson.

McGregor said: “I’m in prime physical condition, I’ve agreed the date with the company.

(Image: Stanislav Krasilnikov/TASS)

“As far as the opponent, I have the opponent’s name, but for me and the game that I’m in, and from experience, if I was to give you people the name - which I would love to do - I know the UFC would flip it because they are a crafty company.

“For me, here’s this one, ask the UFC who the opponent is because I do not give a f*** who the opponent is.

“That will be the beginning of my season.

(Image: Zuffa LLC via Getty Images)

“I will then look to compete against the winner of Nate Diaz and Jorge Masvidal. Obviously, I have history with Nate Diaz, we are set to have the trilogy bout.

“We’ll see how that one goes, I feel Nate will get the better of that one and then we will contest the trilogy bout.

“Then I will seek the Moscow bout and it will be against the winner of Tony Ferguson and Khabib Nurmagomedov.”

(Image: Zuffa LLC via Getty Images)

He added: "I need to be active, I must be active now. We have crossed a hurdle. I have a date.

"Once I am over this first one, once I am there I will continue. I have taken very little damage compared to others in the Octagon. I’m eager to have a good run and compete all over the world."

Here is a run down of 5 opponents he could face in January...

Donald Cerrone

(Image: Zuffa LLC via Getty Images)

The "Cowboy" would represent a testing but not overly outrageous challenge for McGregor's first fight back.

Cerrone, 36, has 12 defeats to his name in his 48 bout career, and lost his last two bouts.

Last time out he was knocked out in the first round of his clash with Justin Gaethje, and was beaten inside two rounds by Tony Ferguson back in June.

He is currently ranked fifth in the lightweight division, would tick all boxes and is one of the most likely.

Justin Gaethje

(Image: SIPA USA/PA Images)

This is a fight the fans would love to see - but it's not a great one to come straight back into after over a year out.

As mentioned, Gaethje made light work of Cerrone, which followed two other first round knockouts in his two bouts previous.

Gaethje would certainly prove more of a risk to McGregor - but after the Irishman slammed Nurmagomedov for running and hiding, perhaps Conor may see this as a case of no risk, no reward.

Max Holloway

(Image: Zuffa LLC via Getty Images)

There has been talk of a rematch between these two since McGregor won their first contest back in 2013.

Holloway remains one of the only fighters to take McGregor to the judges scorecards, and now holds the featherweight championship.

McGregor has made clear his intentions to win back his lightweight belt.

But with Nurmagomedov otherwise occupied, he could go searching for gold elsewhere.

Dustin Poirier

(Image: Zuffa LLC via Getty Images)

The suggestion of a second dust-up with Poirier keeps lingering around despite McGregor remaining adamant that it is not a fight he is interested in.

McGregor knocked out the 30-year-old in 90 seconds in 2014 - although that bout was at featherweight.

Poirier looks a fresh prospect at lightweight, and it took Nurmagomedov almost three rounds to force him into submission in September.

He wants the fight, and has pushed for a rematch before his 31st birthday - which is a day after McGregor's scheduled bout.

And he's teased McGregor, stating: "If it’s that easy [to beat me], just do it again. Try to beat your record."

Given that Poirier is just one spot ahead of him in the rankings, McGregor may well fancy it, particularly as it would make him no.1 contender to face his old foe Nurmagomedov again.

Frankie Edgar

(Image: Zuffa LLC via Getty Images)

This fight looks almost dead and buried, after UFC president Dana White said it "isn't going to happen".

Edgar is currently ranked fourth in the featherweight division, and therefore would offer little but way of a tune-up for McGregor.

However it's the fight McGregor and his trainer want specifically, purely for Edgar's similarity in style to Nurmagomedov.

Both fighters tweeted just this month that they were open to the fight, though White has other plans for Edgar in the bantamweight division.

But what Conor wants, Conor usually gets...
description: The Irishman has laid down proposals for his 2020 season in the UFC after confirming the date of his next bout
